Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The development of ultra-sensitive biological and chemical sensors is one of the grand scientific, engineering, and educational challenges of the 21st century. Under the broad heading of NanoBioSensors (NBS), this Integrative Graduate Education and Traineeship (IGERT) program will address these challenges through an innovative integration of materials for the recognition of target pathogens using sensor platforms that exploit breakthroughs in nanomaterials, miniaturization, sample collection and preparation strategies, and signal detection. It will focus on the development of advanced systems for the rapid, ultra-sensitive detection of pathogens responsible for disease as well as those central to food safety and security and the environment. This program will be strongly embedded in the new, statewide USTAR (Utah Science, Technology, and Research) initiative focused on advancing research and development in NBS, nanomaterials, and biodiagnostic devices. The next generation of research leaders in these areas will require high levels of training in several traditional science and engineering disciplines. This IGERT is designed to lessen longstanding boundaries separating these fields, and establish or expand collaborative ventures in ultra-high sensitivity detection, molecular recognition, surface characterization, interfacial reactivity, micro- and nano-fabrication, and microfluidics. These experiences will be augmented by internships as well as instruction in ethics, creativity, communication, teamwork, and entrepreneurship, all of which play an increasingly vital role in the rapidly evolving scientific and business environments. A diverse group of trainees will be aggressively recruited and actively mentored. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

IGERT: Nanobiosensors, Nanomaterials, and Microfluidics, NSF Award 0903715, The University of Utah

The development of ultrasensitive biological and chemical sensors is one of the grand scientific, engineering, and educational challenges of the 21st century. The popular press is replete with reports of problems stemming from the technical inability to detect toxic materials with respect to homeland security, food safety, and the environment. This Integrative Graduate Education, Research, and Training Program (IGERT) tackled these issues under the banner of Nanobiosensors, Nanomaterials, and Microfluidics through the innovative integration of materials for the highly selective recognition of target pathogens with sensor platforms that encompass breakthroughs in nanomaterials, miniaturization, sample collection and preparation strategies, and signal transduction.

Our IGERT’s principle outcome was realized by orchestrating programs focused on training new scientists and engineers by blurring the longstanding boundaries across several research and technology development areas, including the ultrasensitive detection of disease makers in body fluids and the construction and testing of surfaces designed to selectively bind these markers – all with a strong nanotechnology theme. As a centerpiece to these ends, we developed/refined coursework focused on nanotechnology that reached well beyond trainees matriculating in the traditional scientific and engineering disciplines to include those in mathematics, foreign language, and business. This 3-credit course (“Nanoscience: Where Science and Engineering Intersect”) is now a permanent fixture in the University of Utah’s curriculum offered to upper level undergraduate and first-year graduate students across campus. It is team taught by IGERT faculty, each lecturing in their specialty. The course augments these activities with exercises in ethics, creativity, communication, teamwork, and entrepreneurship, all of which today play an increasingly vital role in rapidly evolving scientific and business environments.

The trainees in our IGERT program have made several exciting scientific research breakthroughs, all of which underscore the interdisciplinary nature of nanoscience and nanotechnology. A few examples include: (1) the development of a test platform designed to identify markers in serum which can potentially be used for the early stage detection of pancreatic cancer; (2) approaches to characterize exosomes, which are cell-derived materials of potential importance to the occurrence of cancer; (3) a medical device capable of alleviating surgical camera fogging and occlusion during minimally invasive surgery, which has resulted in the creation of a trainee-directed small company; (4) electronic devices for the detection of explosives and toxic gases such as hydrogen cyanide, which have been tested for utility in space exploration by NASA; and (5) the study of the mechanism of platelet adhesion in wound healing.

Other aspects of the integrative nature of our IGERT program can be found by examining several self-initiated trainee experiences. In this regard, our trainees have established several scientific society student affiliates. This includes the launch several years ago of the Nanoscience Student Auxiliary of the University of Utah’s Nano Institute of Utah, and, more recently, formation of student affiliates of the Society of Applied Spectroscopy and the Electrochemical Society.
